Re ''Even Doctor-Patient Relationships Can Be Dysfunctional,'' (April 25):

I was once the victim of a medical ''bad fit.'' A chronic asthmatic, I was assigned by my H.M.O. to a ''preventive medicine specialist,'' who tended to dismiss my worries with remarks like ''you don't get enough exercise'' and ''you take too many antibiotics.''
I had been asthmatic for 37 years and was well-qualified to monitor my own condition.
Once, my doctor insisted that because I had had an antibiotic six months earlier, I didn't need one then.
So I ended up in the emergency room for asthma treatment for the first time since I was a very small child.
The expense of this visit made the H.M.O. quite amenable to my insistence the next day that I never have to see this doctor ever again and that I be assigned to a pulmonologist.
Clearly, we had a classic mismatch: a patient who needed to be taken seriously, and a doctor who didn't understand the parameters of her condition.
And, my much more experienced and sensitive pulmonologist has treated my asthma with great success.
